title: Need a sample of text in many languages? Try this...
content:

Similarly, most of the population of the planet is not Moslem, but that doesn’t mean they find quotes from the Qur’an offensive. Just because you don’t subscribe to something doesn’t mean that you find it offensive.

If you are offended by the application of e.g. a fundamentalist protestant interpretation of the Bible to US foreign policy and domestic education policy, that is all the more reason to welcome the presence of scripture within genuinely humanist (in the traditional sense of the word) and scholarly contexts such as the Omniglot website. Chris, the schwa represented by the upside down e is I believe used in the phonetic alphabet for the English sound of the ’e’ in ’the’, when it is pronounced before a consonant: ’the pear’. (In ’the apple’ it becomes a long ’e’.)

The name for the sound I believe comes from Hebrew, which has the same vowel sound in it as the English schwa. (In modern Hebrew it is pronounced schva, though.) In the Hebrew system of vowel points the sound is represented by two dots arranged vertically under the letter. The same sign can also be silent—which way to read it is dictated by complicated rules.

EDIT: I cross posted with Tim. The Wikipedia article has more than you ever wanted to know about the schwa!

My point here—relevant to your and Chris questioning the propriety of using a Biblical text—is that religious texts, including the tower of Babel story, are a part of our cultural heritage, and often they are not religious or sectarian in their connotations—such as the word ’schwa’.

Our history is intertwined with the history of religions and religious texts. Type history in particular is intertwined with the printing of the the Bible, in Latin, Greek, Hebrew,and many other scripts and languages. Hrant, what in the world are you going on about?

I didn’t put up the Omniglot site. [This fellow](http://web.archive.org/web/20080827234827/http:/www.omniglot.com/aboutme.htm) did, and I’m sure from his bio that proselytizing was the furthest thing from his mind. He was just using the oldest familiar story on the origin of many languages to illustrate many languages. He wasn’t endorsing it.

The Tower of Babel story is only directly critical of the Babylonian religion, and that is long, long gone. As its overt target is antique in the extreme, people normally read story as a warning against arrogance, or trying to be a god yourself, or something like that. It is not particularly sectarian, and in fact at least three different religions—Judaism, Christianity and Islam—claim Genesis as their own. Since this particular story doesn’t preach in favor of any sect it is inoffensive to almost everybody, including those like me who take it as myth or legend.

_The Tower of Babel story is only directly critical of the Babylonian religion, and that is long, long gone. As its overt target is antique in the extreme, people normally read story as a warning against arrogance, or trying to be a god yourself, or something like that._

Being a rationalist, as well as religious, I do not take any text as infallible authority, including any religious text. I like to think that a true religiousity, acknowleging the awesome and mysterious powers that sustain us and the universe, will engender an appropriate humility. And often this is the case. There are at least three things wrong with this argument.

First, you are reacting as if the author of the web site is proselytizing for religion, or that any quote of a religious text has to be for the purpose of proselytizing, which is just ridiculous. Many people, including myself, quote religious texts from many religions as well as anti-religious texts, to make points clear and not endorse the views.

Second, as you repeatedly ignore, but is fact, this text is not of one specific religion, but of at least three. Those familiar with this text as a result of being raised in societies with widespread Judaism, Christianity or Islam constitute not a little village but over half of humanity. And if you focus on those peoples who use alphabetic texts—the point of the exercise—it is probably three-quarters of this group. As an English language site, practically everyone will be familiar with the story.

Finally, your dark hints about ’one religion’ and ’little village’ seem to allude to the fact that this is from the Hebrew Bible, and hence Jewish. The idea that this guy has the purpose of proselytizing for Judaism—and I doubt he is Jewish—is laughable. What is “just plain ugly” are your dark hints that quoting anything Jewish is offensive.
